title: Mason Kellerman
text:
I currently attend the University of California, Los Angeles, and will be graduating this spring with Psychology, B.A. and Statistics & Data Science, B.S. degrees, with a minor in Educational Studies.
My focus is on designing effective measures/assessments for teacher and student evaluation, which enable quasi-causal conclusions about underlying features and facilitate constructive educator training and school policy. I care about making a positive impact on individuals with my work through affecting institutional progress. More information about me can be found in my resume.
I am interested in opportunities that further this vision; I appreciate all outreach :)

title: Impact of Socioeconomic Context on Debt Delinquency*
text:
*IN PROGRESS
Team Project
Download the Report here (.pdf)
(get source file here) (.tex)
View poster here
(get source file here) (.tex)
View presentation slides here
(get source file here) (.qmd)




Financial stability is deeply associated with quality of life in the U.S.; the role of contextual factors in economic prosperity is similarly well established.
Using data from Opportunity Insights, my team and I used non-parametric methods of analysis to assess how racial and intergenerational factors lead to differential economic prosperity, as measured by the debt delinquency rate. Since the data is split by U.S. county, we also investigate differences across state and county, incorporating limited environmental factors such as county-level racial diversity.
We compiled a report that contains our findings in more detail, and designed a poster to effectively communicate these results to a mass audience. A set of slides was also created for an in-class presentation.
tools used: R, LaTeX, Quarto







Graphical results (to be updated later):

title: Sports Sabermetric Predictive Comparison Report*
text:
*IN PROGRESS
Download the Report here (.pdf)
(get source file here) (.tex)




This project focused on comparing the predictive abilities of different classes of sabermetric statistics in sports. Using 2025 WNBA data, I developed classification models with the goal of predicting a win/loss outcomes.
Sport fans will be familiar with the divide between classic, ‚Äúold-school‚Äù statistical categories and new, ‚Äúsabermetric‚Äù metrics designed to be a more advanced indicator of performance. Often, one set of these statistics will be favored over others, by both casual fans and award voters alike.
This project seeks to determine whether advanced or basic team statistical categories in sports is more predictive of team success at the team level. The resulting report will show the modeling strategies, test outputs, and corresponding conclusions.
tools used: R, LaTeX







Graphical results (to be updated later):

title: Site Information
text:
The current build is from 30 November 2025.
The website was created by me using Quarto and RStudio. It is hosted with Netlify, and the source code can be found on the public GitHub repo here.
The site typeface is Atkinson Hyperlegible Next (and Atkinson Hyperlegible Mono), an accessibility-focused design created by the Braile Institute (more information here).
Significant thanks to Jose Toledo Luna‚Äôs instructions, which provided much needed instruction.

title: Context-Dependent ABS Challenge Tool*
text:
*IN PROGRESS
Access the Tool here
Download the Report here (.pdf)
(get source file here) (.qmd)




In the upcoming 2026 MLB season, we will see the introduction of an automatic ball/strike (ABS) system which will allow players to ‚Äúchallenge‚Äù the human umpires‚Äô ball/strike calls by appealing to a computerized system. However, since this has never been used at the major league level, optimal (and demonstrated) strategy is yet to be solidified.
This project aims to create a statistical framework for assessing the optimal strategy around using ABS challenges, with reference to game situation (and optionally player and team tendencies as well).
This research is summarized into a pdf report, and used to develop an python-based interactive tool to visualize and experiment with different factors. This dashboard could allow teams and analysts to more easily understand ABS challenge behaviors.
tools used: R, python, Quarto
